text.p: Solidere A and B shares continued to slide on the Beirut Stock Exchange on Wednesday and brokers said they expected them to fall back to levels they maintained before last week's surge.
Solidere A and B both fell to $11 from $11.5 and $11.375 respectively.

"I expect Solidere shares to reach the $10.25-$10.75 levels because of the big supply of A shares dumped in the market," Fouad Salame, Assistant Treasurer at Banque D'Affaires du Liban et D'outre Mer, told Reuters.

The A and B shares hit 16-month highs of $11.75 and $12.25 last week after the company's GDRs soared in London on reports of buying by U.S. and European emerging market funds, but they have fallen back this week.
Banque Libanaise pour le Commerce also fell on Wednesday for the third successive session, to $16.25 from Tuesday's $16.75, after rising sharply for four-and-a-half months.
The other two listed banks, Banque Audi and Bank of Beirut, were unchanged at $20 and $3.5625 respectively.
The LIBX bank index fell 1.01 percent to 137.71. The LISPI general index fell 0.98 percent to 86.64 and the BLOM general index fell 3.26 percent to 953.47.
Salameh said the banks had good fundamentals that should sustain them.
"The fundamentals are there. They should sustain Audi and BOB at their current levels. As for BLC, it should stabilise around $16.25 for a while and then start moving up," he said.
BLC's quarterly profit announced on Monday of $3.39 million excluding $1.8 million realised on the sale of real estate assets was "positively surprising", Salame added.
"The fundamentals are also there for Solidere but as long as there is supply of A shares the stock will keep moving down," he said.
Supply of Solidere A shares at the first fixing was 260,837 to demand of 14,942 shares. Supply of B shares was 103,497 against a demand of 11,500 at the same fixing.
Salame said a zero turnover on the second fixing of A shares on Monday dampened the market. There was no demand on that fixing as opposed to 195,798 shares in supply.
"That was a mistake that should not have happened. It scared investors who thought liquidity was running away. They wanted to sell rather than buy," Salame said.
Total BSE turnover was 216,164 shares for a value of $1,859,785 compared with 201,666 shares and $2,144,311.
There was no trade in the four listed industrial companies: Ciments Libanais, Ciments Blancs, Eternit and Uniceramic.
